author: Cliff Pinckard, Northeast Ohio Media Group
title: Perseid meteor shower under way and skies are mostly clear in Northeast Ohio
text:
CLEVELAND, Ohio â€” The heavens are putting on a show tonight and Thursday night, and the skies over Northeast Ohio are cooperating.
The Perseid meteor shower is expected to be among the brightest in years, according to USA Today , thanks to minimal moonlight.
The key to the best viewing, though, still is finding a place where there is little light pollution, and that's not so easy in Cleveland .
Still, if you can find an unobstructed view away from man-made light, observers could see up to 100 meteors an hour.
Even if you escape the light, it could take time for your eyes to adjust , as long as 20 minutes. It's recommended to take at least an hour to observe.
Also, the early evening isn't the best time to see the meteors, according to EarthSky.org , although there is a chance you could see an "earthgrazer", described as a "loooong, slow, colorful meteor traveling horizontally across the evening sky."
The meteors will become more common after midnight, and peak just before dawn. ( Go here to see livestreaming of the meteor shower from NASA.)
The Perseid meteor shower occurs each year in July and August as the Earth passes through the debris of the Swift-Tuttle comet, according to NASA.
Tonight and early Thursday morning likely are the best chances to see the meteor shower. The National Weather Service is calling for partly cloudy skies and chances of showers and thunderstorms Thursday night and early Friday morning.
